qas.question: Other than private individuals, who has used youtube to grow their audience?
What is the name of youtube's revenue-sharing program?
What was the highest earning youtube partner video producer?
Big pop artists account for how what percentage of the views on youtube?
Which music chart said in 2013 it would start taking youtube data into account for its ratings?

plausible_answers.text: a free-to-use... promotional platform for the music labels

qas.question: How did a 2012 MCU business editor characterize YouTube?

plausible_answers.text: digital-era artists' work must not only be of high quality, but must elicit reactions on the YouTube platform and social media

qas.question: What did Katheryn Thayer say in 2012 about YouTube videos?
What were 2.5% of artists categorized as in 2012?
How many views did the 2.5% of artists receive in 2012?

plausible_answers.text: announced that it was factoring YouTube streaming data into calculation of the Billboard Hot 100 and related genre charts

qas.question: What did Billboard do in early 2012?

context: Both private individuals and <a0_0>large production companies<a0_0/> have used YouTube to grow audiences. Independent content creators have built grassroots followings numbering in the thousands at very little cost or effort, while mass retail and radio promotion proved problematic. Concurrently, old media celebrities moved into the website at the invitation of a YouTube management that witnessed early content creators accruing substantial followings, and perceived audience sizes potentially larger than that attainable by television. While YouTube's revenue-sharing "<a1_0>Partner Program<a1_0/>" made it possible to earn a substantial living as a video producer—its top five hundred partners each earning more than $100,000 annually and its ten highest-earning channels grossing from $2.5 million to <a2_0>$12 million<a2_0/>—in 2012 CMU business editor characterized YouTube as "<b5_0>a free-to-use... promotional platform for the music labels<b5_0/>". In 2013 Forbes' Katheryn Thayer asserted that <b6_0>digital-era artists' work must not only be of high quality, but must elicit reactions on the YouTube platform and social media<b6_0/>. In 2013, videos of the 2.5% of artists categorized as <b7_0>"mega", "mainstream" and "mid-sized"<b7_0/> received <a3_0><b8_0>90.3%<b8_0/><a3_0/> of the relevant views on YouTube and Vevo. By early 2013 Billboard had <b9_0>announced that it was factoring YouTube streaming data into calculation of the <a4_0>Billboard<a4_0/> Hot 100 and related genre charts<b9_0/>.
